Message.Title: Big Deal
Message.Msg: Apple's revenue numbers are so huge, that to grow another 10% is a really BIG DEAL!! Most companies can't even do that type of sales in a whole year. Last year, Apple had $39.19 billion in sales and EPS of 12.30. Now to grow 10%, Apple has to do $43.10 billion in sales and EPS of 13.53. This means an increase of $3.91 billion in sales from last year. Analysts are however expecting Apple to post $42.92 billion in sales and EPS of 10.22 (lower margins) Apple itself provided a guidance between $41 billion and $43 billion (and talked about margins) Any which way you look at it, $43 billion in one quarter is a HUGE NUMBER! How Apple can do $43 billion? By selling 53.75 million iPhones at $800 per phone, or 86 million products in total at an average price of $500 (this could be combination of iPhones, iPads, iPods, Macs, Apple TV). That's a lot of products to sell in one quarter... Higher the ASP of a product, easier to get to the promised number! But, the average price of an Apple product is falling because Apple has introduced lower priced products such as iPad Mini, still sells iPhone 4 (best selling iPhone), and many iPods. Hence, it becomes harder to sell more of these products to achieve the sales number. Apple just did $54.5 billion in December quarter. So, Apple knows how to sell, sell, sell... especially internationally, in China, Japan, India and emerging markets. Apple could still make or beat the sales number. However, EPS could be difficult because of greater percentage of lower margin products including iPad Mini and iPhone 4. Wall Street likes to see growing EPS. If Apple beats revenue by posting $45 billion quarter (15% growth) or in that range, EPS won't matter much.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Problems with new casing colors have pushed back the iPhone 5S launch to calendar Q3 from June, writes Peter Misek in his gloomy note. Misek also expects a cheaper, plastic-bodied iPhone that's otherwise similar to the iPhone 5 (Apple's design philosophy makes this questionable), and believes Sharp's light/low-power IGZO displays will be used in the 5th-gen iPad (more believable). He now predicts an iTV won't arrive this year due to challenges in making "a display that looks like 4K/Ultra HD but without the super-premium cost" - BI observes Misek's iTV forecasts haven't been too accurate.

Message.Title: A little perspective
Message.Msg: In Feb 2007 I came into some money via an estate inheritance and made a decision to buy 2500 shares of apple and got them for 84.25/share. In about 11 months I sold the entire position at 196.26/share and sat on the cash in my trading account for 13 months until I pulled the trigger and doubled down with 5000 shares at 89.31/share where they are still in my account. I watched the price over the years head up to just over 700 and ground my teeth all the way down to current levels. But if history tells me anything from the first drop in half which allowed me to double up, I would highly anticipate that even if growth slows, the market sentiment gets uglier, it matters not when the company is solid and innovative. The reality distortion field may be weaker but make no mistake apple has more tricks up its sleeve and the cost of iphone5 production is dropping. Sure they may have to concede some margins and only make low double digit growth but how many companies are positioned with more cash to chart a course than apple. I see double this level to mid 800's in 13-15 months with history repeating. Should I have sold at 700? Maybe but I'm no seer, and I'll take my chances as this company has already provided my retirement fund 20 years sooner than had I just worked until 65. Nothing is guaranteed but death and taxes, but this company is far too strong to fail. It is blatantly obvious that wall street is beating the #$%$ out of this thing to make money over the next year as they know all too well it rise from the ashes and project phoenix is revealed.... Stay long and be patient. Internet trading has precipitated impatience and infromation sharing has turned stock market trading into sentiment based BS. Not much one can do except day trade, or show resolve and patience. Mark it, June-July 2014 apple is over $800 and still a screaming buy with every naysayer singing a different tune again.

Message.Title: Will The Samsung S4 Launch Drive Apple's Share Price Down?
Message.Msg: I said a couple of days ago we are seeing a different type of innovation in smartphones – Apple, not some start up, wiped out Nokia. Adjacency plays like that are where high risk innovation is played out by the likes of Apple and Amazon. But the S4 is not even an adjacency play. It is an iPhone-like phone, just done a whole lot better than the iPhone itself. But critically it is also being done faster. That is the new nature of innovation, at least one important feature of it. Rene Ritchie had a great piece about Apple’s iPhone about this, especially the Apple release strategy, over on iMore yesterday. He argues is that Apple likes to bring out a truly updated device once every two years. In the interim it will do an update (the S version). Samsung and other smartphone makers have disrupted that pattern by launching new phones, major upgrades anyway, in the S year, taking the shine of Apple’s reputation as an innovator and reducing the impact of Apple’s software advantage. But actually Samsung has done something much more substantial. They are unveiling the S4 less than a year after the S3 launch, which was May 2012. The S3 had an 18 month development cycle. The S3 to S4 product cycle is less than a year. That means they are pressuring Apple not just in the S3 period but in full launch years too. And in addition they have also announced the Note 3. This is pretty dramatic stuff. Forbes

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: “Apple tightly controls its software and hardware, and is fiercely competitive in battling its rivals, especially in the mobile market. And yet, while the company never creates apps for anyone else’s mobile system or device, each of its major mobile-platform foes — Google, Amazon and Microsoft — make many of their apps available for Apple devices,” Walt Mossberg reports for The Wall Street Journal. “If you buy an iPhone or iPad, you get Apple-written mobile apps and services like Siri, iMessage, iWork, iPhoto and FaceTime, which aren’t available on other phones and tablets. But you can [also] get first-class versions of competitors’ official apps,” Mossberg reports. “So, iPhone and iPad users who prefer apps from other big mobile-platform makers don’t have to switch to an Android or Windows Phone or an Amazon tablet. They have access right on their Apple devices to major apps from these competing platforms. But people with non-Apple mobile devices can’t get Apple’s mobile apps and services.”

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: AAPL jumps on India market. Apple’s move up has been prompted at least in part by a major change in the way it sells the iPhone in India, by employing the help of small local retailers to distribute the device, and creating amortized payment plans that defray the significant upfront cost of buying an iPhone in India. Changing the cost/value proposition was key, since Apple’s iPhone is often much more expensive in India than it is elsewhere in the world, and actually getting it to customers proved very difficult using Apple’s previous distribution channels. The iPad mini and iPad 4 launched in India only shortly after its North American release, however, indicating Apple is trying harder to get products to that market early.

I blame - in part - Apple's executives - and especially those in PR - who are not being proactive and who are also not defending Apple's name when it's clearly needed.

Message.Title: Wrong Focus on AAPL
Message.Msg: I watched a 2 year old yesterday at the airport swiping his iPAD with ease. This market is hot with unlimited potential. At the gate everyone (well 90%) was checking their phones. Too much focus is being placed on competition and not the growing market Apple sells into. If you sold 1 phone for example and you were the only company selling phones you would have 100% of the market-share. If the market-share was 100 phones and you sold 65 of them you would only have 65% of the market yet 65 times more opportunity to make money. Apple is not threatened by the increasing number of ankle biters. Samsung has a story but Apple will squeeze them down in the long run. AAPL will soon fly past 500, then 500 on its way to new all time highs.

Topic.Title: How does Yahoo not remove any user with Pharmer**** in the name

Message.Msg: Yahoo! likely won't do ANYTHING that might reduce page activity, which would include removing posts or restricting users. Page hits are ad hits, and ad hits are revenue, and that's all Yahoo! cares about. (They of course have no problem censoring naughty language for fear of alienating certain "sensitive" users, which could again result in reduced site activity and thus lost revenue.)

Message.Title: AAPL no 2 in India
Message.Msg: Wednesday, March 13, 2013, 09:56 am Apple uses mom-and-pop shops to jump into second place in India's smartphone race By Kevin Bostic Apple's increased efforts in the world's second most populous country appear to be paying off, as a new report has the iPhone maker grabbing second place in smartphones behind Samsung in India. CNN reported Wednesday on new figures out from technology market research firm IDC showing that Apple in the fourth quarter of 2012 grabbed 15.6 percent of smartphone revenue in India. Apple rival Samsung remained the top brand in the market, with 38.8 percent market share. Sony (9.4 percent) and Nokia (7.3 percent) rounded out the top four. The research firm estimated in its Asia Pacific Quarterly Mobile Phone Tracker report that smartphone shipments in India were at about five million units for the quarter, up 38 percent from the quarter previous. Smartphone penetration rates in India are estimated to be lower than 10 percent.IDC's estimates jibe with prior reports from the firm that Apple's sales in the country had quadrupled. The sales boom is due to increased efforts on Apple's part to make its premium-priced smartphone offerings available to Indian consumers. Using lessons learned in China, Apple has begun offering installment-based payments for Indian customers. An iPhone in India used to cost nearly a third more than in the United States, with delivery times ranging up to a year. Installment plans make the device more affordable, and Apple has also been selling iPhones on the open market and not through carriers subsidizing the cost of the device with high-margin service contracts.Growth in the Indian market can likely only go so far, though, with Apple's current pricing structure. To better address India, China, and other developing markets, the company is expected to release a lower-cost iPhone some time over the next several months.

Message.Title: Apple Considering Two Options for its Cash Pile
Message.Msg: "On Tuesday, Appleinsider reported that Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL ) will initiate a share buyback program or increase its dividend in order to silence the legion of critics-including David Einhorn-who believe Apple should return some of its $137 billion in cash to its shareholders. Apple is reportedly exploring options but a stock buyback or increased dividend is at the top of its list. David Einhorn's plan has received consideration too. Dubbed the "iPref" plan, Einhorn's idea includes issuing perpetual preferred stock. Einhorn took Apple to court to block the company from bundling four separate issues into one proposal. Einhorn won the case. Apple CEO Tim Cook called the suit a "silly sideshow" but sources said that Apple found the preferred stock idea interesting. With the stock down more than 35 percent and long term investors wondering what happened, Apple is under increasing pressure to do something to return value to its shareholders. Whether that is through a stock buyback in order to put a floor under the stock, a $30 cash dividend -a rumor that made its way around Wall Street last week, or the issuance of preferred shares, it's becoming increasingly clear that Apple knows it has to do something. In an earlier story, Bloomberg reported that Apple would announce its plans for its cash by April. According to the story, Howard Ward, chief investment officer at Gamco Investors Inc. said, "We're going to get an announcement from the company as to how they intend to reallocate some of their cash. They will put a floor under their stock at a higher price than it is today." But two investing titans don't necessarily believe that Apple has an obligation to bow to shareholder pressure. In a CNBC interview, former GE (NYSE: GE ) CEO Jack Welch said, "They'd come after us, 'What are you going to do with all that cash?' Well, we're going to do a smart thing! Trust us!" Welch later said, "Apple deserves, after all they've done, a chance to deliver on all their promises."

He then just cut again to $420 citing 41 in exp sales with 75% chance of hitting that number. So bottom half of range now equals 16% pt drop? And that comes before a highly anticipated buyback which will increase EPS? It doesn't make sense to me.

Message.Title: Apple's iPad is heart of Idaho elementary 'iSchool' pilot program no plastic junk
Message.Msg: Wednesday, March 13, 2013, 10:51 am Apple's iPad is heart of Idaho elementary 'iSchool' pilot program By Neil Hughes A company that specializes in implementing Apple products in the classroom has deployed the iPad to elementary school students in an Idaho pilot program. Paul Elementary School in Minidoka County, Iowa, is where iSchool Campus recently implemented Apple's iPad in its education pilot test. In the program's first two and a half months, students and teachers have been provided with Apple's latest full-size iPad for use in the classroom.In a promotional video posted online, faculty at Paul Elementary praise the iSchool Campus program as an effective way to engage students. Principal Colleen Johnson said the iPad has dramatically changed how her school operates, and she anticipates Apple's tablet will be able to completely replace textbooks in the future."This is our resource, and it's limitless," she said.Fifth-grade teacher Ashlee Johnson said the adoption of the iPad has given students the ability to take ownership of their learning, which fosters genuine excitement in the classroom."They're excited to learn, they're excited to show you what they know," she said. "They're allowed to use their higher computing skills. It allows the kids to be more creative."In addition to boosting education, the iPad has also been a cost saver for Paul Elementary. The principal revealed that her school has reduced paper copies by 20,000 a month in doing digital, resulting in what she called a "significant financial savings.""We don't need consumables anymore," Principal Johnson said. "We're able to use the iPad to take notes, to practice skills. It replaces almost every worksheet that we used to give students, and is much more engaging."The iSchool Campus program also integrates Apple's Mac computers into the classroom. In the video, students can be shown completing assignments on iMac desktops. Principal Johnson said she believes the iPad's effect on students is al

Message.Title: Serious question for those interested in exchanging thoughts
Message.Msg: Assuming in CY13 a new iPhone release of at least 2 sizes, an iPad refresh (full size and mini) and a new product (TV, Watch, something else) along with some cash deployment (dividend increase or larger buyback) and an arrangement with China Mobile - where does the stock price stand at the end of the year. I ask it this way because it seems fairly certain that all of these things will happen this year (the only questionable one is the new product) - Apple product developers and engineers are NOT sitting around getting paid to do nothing. If you believe that, you have no business handling any amount of money more so investing it in this rigged market. All these things in the proverbial pipeline and we have "serious" analysts calling for more downside in the stock? That is beyond my comprehension. FWIW, I think these are real catalysts that amount to at least $650 sometime this CY.

Message.Title: 1 Trillion Dollars was pulled out of the Stock Market by redemption...
Message.Msg: the public is simply glad to have gotten back their money out of the crash of 2008... this will create a stalling point in the market until some new money steps back into equities... but the small investor may be pulling out of the stock market at the wrong time... earnings are strong and improving, interest rates are low, inflation is in check, and valuation of P/E is considered cheap by most historic records kept... now when we hear this from huge money managers and value investing money managers we tend to think why is the P/E so cheap? must be for a reason, right? that is why the stock market is never wrong, they get it right most of the time... so something has them spooked to keep the P/E low... but the 10-year-bond return is well under any quality growing stock that has a nice dividend... so why be in bonds? well folks they are buying bonds, and they are buying stocks, but managers are telling you all that stocks are the better bargain and we tend to agree with that when the S&P 500 was 1250 but now we are 1560... and yet the consumer which is nearly 75% of the economy was thought to be out of money and tapped out on credit cards is not so much the truth... consumer household debt DROPPED this past couple of years, housing has been in a recovery and with low rates there isn't much reason not to lock in a low rate on a relatively lower priced housing market... are the big money managers getting it right? are the bears just looking at the # on the S&P 500 and saying oh that is just too high cuz it was a low # a year or two ago?... someone is going to win this hockey puck face off... which side are you on?

Topic.Title: Capitulation?

Message.Msg: Institutions are the ones who have driven the price to where it is now. Them, and hedgers and some funds. But it hasn't been "capitulation" yet ..... it's been actually a fairly orderly profit-taking binge, coupled with some sporatic spikes by bargain hunters. The negativity on Apple itself is increasing, and reaching a degree that may lead to actual capitulation. It will be evident once the share price breaks through it's current support ..... that will be the straw that breaks the backs of many current supporters, who will just throw in the towel and move on.

Topic.Title: silence on a day when they could create some news.

Message.Msg: Apple management knows if price stays low until August, this benefits company and longs the most due to ASR based on average price for the year. Apple and Tim Cook are willing to take all the bad press to receive 40% more on their purchase. They are very shrewd and your are the idiot. In August 2012, the Company entered into an accelerated share repurchase program (“ASR”) with a financial institution to purchase up to $1.95 billion of the Company’s common stock in 2013. In exchange for an up-front payment of $1.95 billion, the financial institution committed to deliver a number of shares during the ASR’s purchase period, which ends later in 2013. The total number of shares ultimately delivered, and therefore the average price paid per share, will be determined at the end of the purchase period based on the volume weighted average price of the Company’s stock during that period. In the first quarter of 2013, 2,582,782 shares were initially delivered to the Company. This does not represent the final number of shares to be delivered under the ASR. These shares were retired and accounted for as a reduction to shareholders’ equity in the Company’s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet. The Company accounted for the ASR as a repurchase of common stock for purposes of calculating earnings per share and as a forward contract indexed to its own common stock which met all of the applicable criteria for equity classification, and, therefore, was not accounted for as a derivative instrument.

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: With an extreme move in investor sentiment, shares of Apple are turning more attractive on a risk/reward basis, though they probably still should be viewed as a trading sardine not an eating (or investing) sardine. I still believe that most earnings forecasts for the company are too high (based on a more competitive business backdrop), but even if, as I fear, margins are vulnerable, this has likely been discounted at current price levels. Despite the share price schmeissing, Apple’s stable of applications and products will remain a dominant factor in the markets it serves. Investors’ disappointing reaction to the recent trends in the company’s product offerings might be transitory as the company begins to upgrade its portfolio and continues to innovate.

Message.Title: Samsung's marketing money
Message.Msg: My guess is that at least part of the recent negative media is the result of Samsung's latest biggest marketing money. Pull AAPL share price down is not the Samsung's goal, but unfortunately, the market MMs appear to utilize this opportunity to knock AAPL share price down. Just to be realistic, yes, AAPL's margin is going to be lower, it's market share is going to be lower after more and more vendor/markers rushing in to share the pile, but iphne/ipad is not going to lose it's advantage over night or just in couple quarters. Based on IDC's data, yes, AAPL's tablet share will be from 51% to 45% (assume it's a good guess) in 2013, but IDC also says the whole table market is going to grow from 2012's 120m to 2013's 190m, some simple calculation suggests ipad will still grow about 40% in 2013. I would say it's really good grow, but the headline simply says "Apple is going to lose the table market share, from 51% to 45%" and forgot the 40% growth. For longs, I would suggest let's just forget the dividends and buy back increase, this is more and more like a trap for someone to manipulate the share price, to use the rumor to pull the price couple points high, then knock it down the next day with "oops, no announcement". If it comes, good, screw up the shorts. If not, the current P/E and estimated growth rate should be good enough for the current price, enjoy the 2.5%.

Topic.Title: If Apple buys Netflix would that open every device with Netflix to Apple's iTune Store?

Message.Msg: Nextflex is on all Samsung smart TV. With 10B (netflex's price tag) Apple can build their own streaming business. Video streaming is winning against the traditional DVD delivery, but it also actually brings the bar lower for entering into this market, if you have big server/data center and if you big pie of cash to negotiate with content owner. But I would assume/guess the margin in video rental is not good enough for Aapl to jump in. We are talking about "lower" margin is the trigger for that $300 + share price drop, right?

Message.Title: READ - VERY IMPORTANT - THIS WAS LAST YEAR'S CALL
Message.Msg: Last Year, this is how the company announced the 45 Billion 3-year buyback and dividend program. Monday 3/18/12, they announced that a conference call will come Tuesday 3/19/12, pre-marekt. Apple Conference Call WHAT: Tim Cook, Apple’s CEO, and Peter Oppenheimer, Apple’s CFO, will host a conference call to announce the outcome of the Company’s discussions concerning its cash balance. Apple® will not be providing an update on the current quarter nor will any topics be discussed other than cash. WHERE: Via conference call. The dial-in number for press is (877) 616-0063 (toll-free) or (719) 219-0041. Please enter confirmation code 592016. WHEN: Monday, March 19, 2012 at 6:00 a.m. PDT/9:00 a.m. EDT Then on 3/19/12, the actual announcement of the program: Apple Announces Plans to Initiate Dividend and Share Repurchase Program Expects to Spend $45 Billion Over Three Years CUPERTINO, California—March 19, 2012—Apple® today announced plans to initiate a dividend and share repurchase program commencing later this year. Subject to declaration by the Board of Directors, the Company plans to initiate a quarterly dividend of $2.65 per share sometime in the fourth quarter of its fiscal 2012, which begins on July 1, 2012. Additionally, the Company’s Board of Directors has authorized a $10 billion share repurchase program commencing in the Company’s fiscal 2013, which begins on September 30, 2012. The repurchase program is expected to be executed over three years, with the primary objective of neutralizing the impact of dilution from future employee equity grants and employee stock purchase programs. “We have used some of our cash to make great investments in our business through increased research and development, acquisitions, new retail store openings, strategic prepayments and capital expenditures in our supply chain, and building out our infrastructure. You’ll see more of all of these in the future,” said Tim Cook, Apple’s CEO. See that last line - you'll see MORE!!!

Topic.Title: Class action suit against CNBC

Message.Msg: Agreed. There's definitely manipulation taking place. Shorts got lucky with a stock thats been taken hostage by the big money on Wall St. Hedge funds like (Goldman Sachs) and the media (CNBC ) are partners in a conspiricy to bring AAPL to its knees on a giant short bet. In all my years playing the market, I have never seen a stock fall so precipitiously with a complete disconnect to either technicals or fundamentals. This is blatent corruption which will only leave the big money to trade the market. Since the SEC is largely ineffective, the retail investor is losing confidence and s will continue to retreat in larger & larger numbers. Since September 2012, CNBC has made hundreds of unrelenting attacks on AAPL, leaving a long documented video record of both there libilous claims, and the stock dropping immediatly after they finish trashing the stock. Even the threat of a lawsuit may change their biased reporting, and the sooner the better. Indeed, CNBC is not impervious to a backlash where the actual program credibility, and their employees jobs, (Melissa Lee) may well be at stake.

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: Kelleher cut his fiscal 2013 EPS estimate from $47.05 per share to $45.50 per share, and cut his fiscal 2014 estimate from $54.99 per share to $52.97 per share. He now sees a long-term EPS growth rate of 13%, down from a prior 15%. Kelleher adds that he still recommends the stock, based on factors such as the stocks inexpensive valuation and the company’s brand loyalty: A t the same time, we are reiterating our BUY rating on AAPL shares, which appear much more attractive at current levels than they were six months ago. AAPL retains enormous brand cachet and loyalty; the first attribute helps it cultivate growth in emerging markets, while the second helps it hold share in established markets. Although device price is a consideration in selecting a mobile phone, total cost of ownership – including a monthly data plan – mutes the relative advantage of lower-cost devices, particularly those that lack Apple’s ease of use. While Apple’s growth has slowed, the company has sufficient growth and operating leverage to preserve margins near current levels, in our view.

"Shares of BlackBerry (BBRY) started surging about a quarter past 3 pm, Eastern time, after spending most of the session in the red, and are up $1.18, or 8%, at $15.65, after the company this afternoon announced that “one of its established partners has placed an order for one million BlackBerry 10 smartphones, with shipments starting immediately,” adding “This order marks the largest ever single purchase order in BlackBerry’s history.” The BlackBerry Z10 smartphone went on sales in early February after a January debut, in limited release outside the U.S., and yesterday went on sale as a pre-0rder at AT&T (T), with general availability on March 22nd. BlackBerry head of global sales Rick Costanzo is quoted as saying, An order for one million devices is a tremendous vote of confidence in BlackBerry 10. Consumers are ready for a new user experience, and BlackBerry 10 delivers. With strong partner support, coupled with this truly re-invented new platform, we have a powerful recipe for success. In addition, Verizon Communications (VZ) a short while ago said the Z10 will be available on its network starting March 28th, and that it will take pre-orders tomorrow."

Message.Msg: From the facts of the below message from 2/7/13, they already are repurchasing. Only 10 billion of the 45 billion was for buybacks, so I expect a huge buyback increase announced next week with a modest diviidend increase. Looks like they have only spent 10 billion as of 2/15/13: February 7, 2013 Statement by Apple: By early last year, Apple’s cash balance had built to a point beyond what we needed to run our business and maintain flexibility to take advantage of strategic opportunities, so we announced a plan to return $45 billion to shareholders over three years. As of next week we will have executed $10 billion of that plan. We find ourselves in the fortunate position of continuing to generate large amounts of cash, including $23 billion in cash flow from operations in the last quarter alone. Apple’s management team and Board of Directors have been in active discussions about returning additional cash to shareholders.

Jefferies Cuts Apple Price Target to $420
Message.Msg: In a research note, Jefferies said there is a 25% chance the consumer tech giant will miss its already downbeat revenue forecast for the current quarter, explaining that suppliers are “having problems with the new casing colors” for the new iPhone 5S. Jefferies added that while Apple was hoping to pull the product update forward, it will likely be delayed until at least July. A low-cost iPhone will see a delay as well, the bank said. The investment bank also was eyeing an iTV release later this year, but now believes it will launch in 2014.

Topic.Title: Pure manipulation

Message.Msg: When you say "three missed quarters", what criteria are you exactly using? Apple's missed status was guaged by the same "analysts" who predicted it would shoot up to $1000 a share within a short time. These very same analysts maintained highly unrealistic expectations for the company, and when it didn't live up to them, they began to crucify it one after another. So, in today's world, "missed" is a pretty subjective assessment. This company has much higher growth than intc, csco and msft ahead of it, and yet its stock is deemed far less valuable than the aformentioned companies'. That's what makes you think twice about the possibilty of manipulation. Of course, Apple's management and board members are not faultless in creating this fiasco.

Message.Title: Hold long-term and don't worry about the daily swings!
Message.Msg: If you hold long-term why should one care about daily swings? Blackberry was up 8% today because they have an order for 1 million phones. Apple sold 47.8 million iPhones last quarter. They also made 23 billion in cash, just last quarter and promised to return more cash to its shareholders. That means in addition to the 3-year 45 billion plan announced last year on 3/19/12. The company stated they have used approximately 10 billion of the original 45 billion as of 2/15/13. That means roughly 7.5 billion towards dividends and only 1.5 billion on buybacks. Of course that was as of 2/15, so who knows if they have bought back shares since that announcement. They are almost certain to announce an increased share buyback and an increase dividend yield very soon. No reason to worry about the day to day swings until the announcement. The company already stated they will return more cash to us, so why not wait for the announcement? Do what you need to do for your situation, but selling out is exactly what these swings are intended to do. The purpose is to get people angry and sell low. If you sold though, don't be upset when you see the stock's price in 18-months! GLTA Longs!

Message.Title: Does Apple Have A Chief Technology Officer?
Message.Msg: "Leaked tech specifications for Samsung’s next Galaxy smartphone show it to be a high powered device, with nearly seven times the processing speed of the iPhone 5 and a high-end camera and screen. The device could be an iPhone killer if Apple doesn’t release an anticipated and updated iPhone 5S — even then, the device may be playing catch-up with the specs of the Galaxy S IV and could be more on line with the HTC One. The specifications on the Samsung device show a 1.8GHz eight-core Exynos processor and 2GB of RAM. It will also taut advancements on the other high spec features expected from flagship smartphones. For comparison, the iPhone 5 has a 1.2 GHz dual-core processor and 1 GB of RAM, the Nokia (NYSE:NOK) Lumia 920 has a 1.5GHz dual-core processor and 1GB of RAM, and the BlackBerry (NASDAQ:BBRY) Z10 matches the Lumia 920, but with 2GB of RAM. This means Samsung may be coming out with a device with almost seven times the power of the current iPhone... "It allegedly will feature a 5in HD 1080p screen similar to the one found on the Sony Xperia Z, and will be powered by Samsung's eight-core Exynos 5 processor. We're assuming that it will come with Google's Android 4.2 Jelly Bean moble operating system too, skinned in Samsung's Touchwiz UI, which reportedly will bring an eye-scrolling feature to the Galaxy S4."... Samsung S IV Wireless Power Blasted By Lightning From Nikola Tesla Coils "The details on Samsung are more specific, claiming that the Galaxy S IV will feature Qi wireless charging technology run by the Wireless Power Consortium. Users will reportedly be required to buy replacement back covers and an accessory charging pad to be able to recharge their handset without plugging in a cable."

Message.Msg: Unfortunately it will not happen in our lifetime. Apple makes a quality product, however, they have not had an innovative product since the iPad. They just continue to update existing products, and try to hype everything in the media. While they have been able to sell in the US, their arrogance and lack of innovation, does not bode well for them going forward. They missed earnaings in Q3 2012, and the stock ran up to 700 strictly on rumors, not on substance. They missed again in Q4 , the busiest season, and it came back to pre run up levels. They will miss again in the next 2 quarters, due to no new products and margins being compressed. $325 is a realistic end point, until they come up with another innovative product (iWatch will NOT do it)! All the best to those of you drinking the cool aid, unfortunately this will end like Jonestown in mid 2014.

Message.Msg: Wow all the rage against a bonehead comment only meant to mock the ludicrous comments from both bashers and pumpers. How bout this for a more relevant comment from a one time Apple product fan. I use to, until very recently, purchase nothing but Apple products. 2 time iPhone buyer iPad2 and MBA, but when upgrading from iPhone 4 last year I went SG3. I use to love the iPhone but anyone who plays with a top Android phone quickly sees that iOS is looking very long in the tooth. SG4 only widens gap but it's really Googles focus on Android enhancements that's the difference not so much the h/w. I am also getting a Nexus 7, Mac mini pricing is ridiculous given the specs. I will always use a MBA , an awesome machine, however, we all know that isn't the growth segment. Apple will of course always be a force but I for one am sad to see its innovation dry up. Is it just Cook? Who knows.

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: (Reuters) - China Mobile Ltd hopes to tap pent-up demand for Apple Inc smartphones by rolling out new 4G technology this year and having an iPhone model that will finally run on it. The world's largest mobile carrier - with more than twice as many subscribers as there are people in the United States - already has more than 10 million of its customers owning an iPhone even though the gadget doesn't properly work with the Chinese firm's homegrown TD-SCDMA 3G technology, which is not compatible with global technologies. That inferior technology, and the failure to offer customers an iPhone contract - which its main rivals do - has been a key reason for China Mobile's slowing profit growth.

Message.Title: Samsung Innovating Faster Than Apple Says Piper Jaffray Analyst Gene Munster
Message.Msg: Munster was discussing the Korean company on Bloomberg TV on Wednesday, ahead of the expected launch of the Samsung Galaxy S IV smartphone on March 14. “What [Samsung] are doing is they’re innovating faster,” Munster said, according to MacDailyNews. “I don’t know if they’re necessarily ahead of where Apple is, but just the pace that they’re coming out with [products] is so much faster, so think of it this way: iPhone comes out on an annual basis, Samsung comes outs with an impactful phone on a monthly basis and two or three really big phones a year. And so, the technology, I guess, that they’re actually working on, they’re able to get it to market a little bit faster.”... The Galaxy S IV is expected to be launched in New York City on March 14 with an eight-core Exynos processor, a separate eight-core graphics processing unit, a 4.99-inch Super Amoled display, 2GB of RAM, a 13-megapixel rear camera with 1080p video capability, a 2-megapixel front-facing camera, and the latest version of Android. According to IBB analyst Jefferson Wang, the Galaxy S IV will be Samsung’s “last act in Apple’s shadow.”

Message.Title: Big Data’ Generates Big Returns - But Local Corp is the Big Data-Company of the Local Search
Message.Msg: Big Data’ Generates Big Returns: Q&A With VC Roger Ehrenberg By Lauren Lyster Big data” investment is accelerating in the world of venture capitalists and the tech startups they are funding. The big data theme has attracted nearly $5 billion of funding over the past five years, according to the VC database CB Insights; 2012 was the biggest year of deals so far, seeing 19.5% growth from the previous year. Roger Ehrenberg, founder of venture capital firm IA Ventures, has harnessed this admittedly “fruit of the day” moment by raising money to invest in startups solely around a big data theme. He has raised $155 million to back early-stage startups, partnering with entrepreneurs to help build their businesses from the beginning. He then takes a real hands-on approach in helping to develop the companies, something he says many VCs used to do and then got away from. Ehrenberg sat down with Yahoo!Finance for a fireside chat at South by Southwest (SXSW) in Austin on Saturday. Here are some highlights. What does "big data" mean? (Ehrenberg has been quoted as saying the term has become so beloved by the media that it has gone from “hackneyed” to “worthless.”) I do think it’s a stupid term. But I break it down as enabling technologies in platforms and applications that by themselves create unique defensible data assets...I would say an example would be a company like Simple, a retail bank optimized for your mobile device. They collect all kinds of interesting information from where and when you swipe your Simple card...They know so much about you that’s not inferred, it’s actual because people are doing real transactions, using a Simple card in lieu of a credit card.

Message.Title: Apple will Buy Back around $350, not sooner
Message.Msg: The way TC and Apple see it, Wall Street has already crushed them hard. Why give in to Wall Street pressure? What's the point of buying back at this level. Might as well wait until Wall Street crushes them further, get all the weak hands out of the way, and then re-build around the $350 level. Remember what Warren Buffett advised TC... his company stock dropped 50% four times, and they came back up each time. In essence, he is telling TC that let the stock drop further, around the 50% mark. And find that moment to buy when you can buy at the best price... 80 cents on the dollar. Think about it? Why would Apple buy now above $400, when it knows that Wall Street will more likely bring the stock down further after the earnings. The prudent thing would be then to wait and see how Wall Street plays out the game, and buy when you can buy the most for the lowest possible price. Apple should be in NO HURRY to buy back. Unfortunately, TC and Apple's strategy does not help the retail investor in the short term, at least until the dust settles. What do you all think?

Topic.Title: Ok gang. So what will happen tomorrow? I have no clue

Message.Msg: conventional logic says it will go down due to such a big unveiling by a major competitor. Unfortunately, (or fortunately in this case) conventional logic and stocks prices don't always go together. Take the day Q1 was released. Apple beat guidance and beat estimates, but expectations were so much higher, and the stock lost almost 10% immediately. Now take the Galaxy S4 launch tomorrow, expectations are so high, and much of the info about the phone has already been released. I think though the S4 will probably be the most impressive smart phone on the market when it comes out, the expectation for something new or innovative probably won't be there, and though a great phone, tomorrow is very likely to be a disappointment for Samsung and possibly a very up day for Apple as everyone will now look to the 5S launch.

Topic.Title: Samsung will never beat AAPL in quality or brand

Message.Msg: Samsung plays in the low-end, cheap phone market. Their consumers are looking for cheap phones. These consumers will never be Apple consumers. Apple is high-end, high-quality. Apple will never win on market share and they don't care. Just like BMW will never sell more cars than Toyota and the other low-end providers. BMW is high-end, high-quality. They are not looking for the most market share. This marketing 101. I laugh when the articles come out saying Samsung is leading Apple in market share. They always will. There are tens of millions of more people making lower incomes in this country who will never be able to afford Apple products. That is fine. These people will also never buy a BMW, Lexus, Rolex, stay at a Ritz Carlton, eat at a five-star restaurant or drink a $100 bottle of wine. So what. These brands don't care about the low-end consumers. It's called market segmentation.

Message.Title: Yet Anolther Apple Price Target Cut. Argus Cuts From 775 to 600
Message.Msg: “Shares of Apple (AAPL) continued to hold gains during the afternoon part of the session, though it sold off in the closing minutes, ending down 8 cents at $428.35,” Tiernan Ray reports for Barron’s. “At the same time, however, Argus Research‘s Jim Kelleher, who has a Buy rating on the shares, this afternoon cut his price target on the stock to $600 from a prior $775, after Kelleher cut his estimates for the year to reflect lower iPhone sales amidst a ‘proliferation’ of smartphone models at lower price points, and to reflect a greater mix of the lower-price iPad mini in tablet sales,” Ray reports. “Kelleher thinks smartphone competition is outstripping Apple’s ability to stick with a single new model each year,” Ray reports, “He sees the company coming up with an ‘iPhone 5S’ refresh in the late summer, and a cheaper iPhone for emerging markets by the end of the year.”
